ContentClassification.TableReference: D. Barrett and B.A. Edwards, et all., “The Institute of Actuaries of Australia Mortality Investigation IA 1990-92M and F, Graduated Mortality Tables”, Institute of Actuaries of Australia (1994). Accessed: January, 2014 from http://www.actuaries.asn.au/Library/Reports/1994/MortalityTables9092.pdf
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Institute of Actuaries of Australia 1990-92 – Male (IA90-92M). Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 99.
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Mortality of Australian personal business insured lives over the three years 1990-1992 based on data provided by twelve offices. Policies used were whole of life and endowment insurances, both with and without term insurance riders, issued on standard lives. The data were subdivided by sex (Male, Female, and Undifferentiated). The “Undifferentiated” category consists almost entirely of older policies which offices submitting data to the investigation believe to be predominantly older male lives and for the purpose of producing the tables were included with “Males”. Methodology: Initial mortality rates were first calculated from the data using LIFETIME, a demographic package developed at Macquarie University. The smoothness of the mortality rates produced by LIFETIME was less than satisfactory at certain ages for both sexes, and further smoothing was therefore achieved by using a running average of seven terms over the main part of the age range. Rates for ages 97 to 99 developed using Gompertz Law. To compensate for the upwards distortion inherent in the running average smoothing process, the smoothed rates were further adjusted by fitting a quadratic (males) or cubic (females) through selected values of the ratios actual to expected. Graduated ultimate rates for males with both a two-year and a five-year select period were produced, but proved to be very similar. For this reason it was decided to adopt a two-year select period officially. Select rates have not been produced as the number of deaths at the early durations is insufficient to provide meaningful graduated rates. Data Transcription Errors. None. Data Certified: 01/2014

MetaData.TableDescription: Institute of Actuaries of Australia 1990-92 – Male (IA90-92M). Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 99
